segments.text: Today's date is December 18th, 1981.
This is a test.
Testing.
Testing, testing.
This is a test.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is interview number two with General Ludeke.
Today's date is Wednesday, January 27th, 1982.
This is tape three.
Last time, this is our second interview with General Ludeke.
Today is the 27th of January, 1982.
Last time we were talking about the position that you had from July 43rd to February 46th, which is on page four of your .
We were talking about the position of deputy chief of staff for operations, plans, trainings, intelligent, and communications.
Army Air Force, Southeast Asia Command, and the China, India, Burma Theater.
And the last thing that you talked about was your views about Chiang Kai-shek, and we covered that.
And I was wondering about a couple of other people who are very important.
One was Hap Arnold and another one was Mountbatten, Lord Mountbatten, and I'd like you to give your views on those two men.
Did you ever meet them?
You must have met them.
Yes, I did.
General Arnold was Major Arnold when I first met him and he was in command of March Field, California.
when I went to Marshfield, first out of flying school, as a cadet.

Everyone at Marshfield was away flying air mail at that, when I arrived there, so it was a case of going on to a post and not being able to call on a commanding officer for nearly four months because we had to
get him home for, and so I met him when he did, was able to come home.
And served under him in one capacity or another until 1937, and then
By the time I got back from Panama, he was chief of staff of the Air Force, Army Air Forces.

And after I got out of the intelligence command, which was under Army, and joined back with the Air Force, well then I was under him again, but I joined back with the Air Force in order to go to India.
This was just prior to Admiral Mountbatten's arrival in India to take over as Viceroy as well as Commander, Southeast Asia Command.
So, and I went there at that time to be
Chief of Staff Operations for U.S. Air Forces, CBR, in New Delhi and attended many of the conferences in planning and operations of the Southeast Asia Command under Mountbatten.
And I got to know him very well in that capacity.
Later we went to Cairo to the Sexton Conference and this was his first major command conference after having taken over as Supreme Commander Southeast Asia Command.
And in Cairo I served him among others as an air planner.
for many of the presentations and papers that were presented at, at the Sexton, uh, conference.
It was a very interesting conference in many respects, but in our limited area that was present at the conference, uh, Admiral Mountbatten, the new Supreme Commander, uh, Chiang Kai-shek,
who I think expected to be the Southeast Asia commander, and Madame Chang, of course, was with him.
General Joe Stilwell, who was the senior American commander in India.
Sir Oliver Leese, who was the senior British commander in India.
All vying for the limited resources that
the combined chiefs of staff might be able to make available for that theater.
So it was a very interesting time.
Back in India, after Cairo, when we returned, all of the air forces in India, American, British, Canadian, Australian,
one New Zealand squadron, Indian, were all integrated into one operational force called the Southeast Asia Air Command.
General Stratmire was made commander of that Southeast Asia Air Command, and I retained my job as
deputy chief of staff operations, plans, training, and intelligence for that new command.
And so we operated all of the air forces in India through that mechanism out of General Stratmire's headquarters and all of the operational things out of my office.
This included not only all of the tactical and defensive air and offensive bombardment air and all, but air transport as well.
And in that theater during the war, air transport was probably the most important single element of a military capability in the whole pit.
at least it was the most controversial because everybody wanted it.
One incident concerning Mountbatten, it's worth recording I think and at least in my notes.
The Japanese at one point had penetrated India to the point of surrounding
which was a British major base and outpost on the border between Burma and India, and had held it during the worst part of the monsoon season.
We, the Air Forces, had to go in and fly out nearly half a million civilians
and fly in food for everybody, including one corps of British troops who stayed inside.
And, of course, it became a little urgent that somebody get moving to get that situation changed.
Well, in an area where the rainfall is 300 inches a year, it's a little bit difficult.
And all of the support that they got had to come by air, and very limited air that we had available.
In any situation where ground personnel have to be supplied by air, you can almost write the conversations before the operations start.
Because the man on the ground just doesn't have anything like what he needs to do his job.
The man on the air side of that picture knows he has delivered to him ten times what he needs to do any job that might be presented to him.
And so there's never a give.
That situation just remains the same.
The British troops we thought were so spoiled that
they wouldn't carry their four o'clock tea.

They would have us drop it at three-thirty, wherever they happened to be, which was true in many circumstances, although not all of them, and I certainly don't mean anything derogatory about the British troops, but they get spoiled, everybody gets spoiled.

the commander up at Imphal, a corps commander, a major general in the British Army, was trying to get his corps ready to jump off from Imphal and push the Japanese back across the Irrawaddy River and start moving down through Vermont.
But it didn't seem that he could ever get the weather, the supply situation, and everything else in a situation, in a condition that he felt more to push it off.
Well, Mountbatten got a little upset about this.
Finally flew out of his headquarters down in Salon and went straight into M-Fall on his airplane.
see what was the matter.

And he was told while he was there that the air supply just hadn't been built up enough that he could afford to move, and he'd just have to wait until we could build up the air supply a little bit more.
Well, Mountbatten kind of hit the ceiling,
what the hell's the matter with those air people because that wasn't the kind of story he was getting from them.
So he got in his airplane and took off for Calcutta where we were and where the headquarters of the ground forces were also.
Sent word to General Stratmire's headquarters that he wanted Strat over there at Barracore when he landed.
He wanted to talk to him.
And General Stratton called me on the intercom and told me to get my figures together on whatever I thought might be subject to the conversation and let's go.
So I did, and I also got my supply man, a Brigadier Bastien, who was a British brigadier general.
And we crawled in the boat and went across the Hooli over to Bearport.
But the Admiral had already landed and was there ahead of us.

So as we came into the Sir Oliver Lee's office area, big, pretty good sized building in there, the Admiral came out and met General Stratton, or met all of us, but General Stratton was leading us, coming down the hall, and he had his finger, you know, tell him something, you see.
And General Stratton's a funny kind of a man, a real fine gentleman that certain things he doesn't, he draws a line on.
He reached out and caught the Admiral's finger right there.
And he said, I might just bite that thing off.
And the admiral, of course, was most embarrassed and most apologetic and everything else, but he just got away from it and do it.

Well, we went on in and the officers sat down and the admiral told us what his problem was and he wanted to get going and he didn't seem to be able to get the air supply and the other things to match up.
I reminded the Admiral that we had sent him a wire yesterday laying out what the situation was, and it hadn't changed.
And as far as we knew, they were ready to go, and we didn't know what else they needed.
I said, by the way, would you like to know what our last two airplane loads were this morning?
He said, yes, I would.
I said, remember, they're outdoor toilet seats.
and he looked as though he thought that was absolutely incredible, and relaxed a minute and said, until he used to get General so-and-so, I've forgotten his name, up on the phone, which he did.
The Admiral told him if he wasn't across that chimney by four o'clock the next morning, he would have to look up to a lance corporal.
Look up to a lance corporal.
Lance corporal, yeah.
Well, we got things all straightened out and started to leave and went outside and I knew some of the, a lot of the British officers that was there.
One of them was outside, he wasn't privileged to be in with all them.
And he said, what's he had a mouth power in that?
I said, well he was talking to Donald so-and-so up at Imphal.
He said, well why the hell doesn't he use the phone?
No, but I thought that was a wonderful man, and a very dedicated and understanding man.
He had a hard road to hold.
Prime Minister Churchill was looking right down his throat on everything.
So he had some real problems, but I thought he was a wonderful man and did a wonderful job.
Did that major general move out that next morning?
Yes, he did.
He didn't have any problems either.
He didn't have any problems with his toilet seats?
No, he didn't.
We followed with air support, and the weather was reasonable enough that we could do it.
And what we found was that the Japanese had occupied Dakang and then they'd been cut off from their supplies and they were damn near starved to death and it was just a riot.
Just routed them out and there was not really no fight to it at all because they weren't in a position to hold anything.
They were just hungry.
Which leads you to all kinds of other things.
Why the hell didn't we know that?
How come we fed all those millions or hundreds of thousands of people out there all that time when we didn't need to, and a lot of other things, but you can't answer those questions in retrospect.
Not this far, indeed.
I was wondering about another thing.
Generally, how would you describe Anglo-American relations?
in your theater?
In the theater, in India, Anglo-American relations were not good.
I'm talking about between military people.
I'm not mixing in the civilians and the Indians and all that sort of thing.
I'm talking about Why were they not good?
They were not good because General Joe Stilwell
did not get along with any of the British people that he had to work with there.
And their objectives were not the same.
If one said, who's right, or whatnot, you'd have to say, well, hell, they obviously were both wrong, which they were.
The British, I must say, were
not a damn bit bashful about using American things or using us in any way they could.
For example?
For example, reversal and lease.
They would ride our airplanes any time they got their thumb work.
I never said a word, but if we wanted to ride one of their airplanes,
We got a pass onto that airplane, and it got charged back through the channels.
And their government collected for air travel.
But they had no mechanism whereby we could do this.
That's just one little example.
And there are thousands of others.
And of course, the dam's not bigger than that.
And people didn't like that attitude.
And there were a lot of things about us that they didn't like.
Uncle Joe Stilwell wanted to go into Burma and kick the Japs out of there.
Well, from the British point of view, there were a hell of a lot of things a lot more important than that.
And a hell of a lot higher priority than that over there.
So they didn't agree.
And Chiang Kai-shek, of course, didn't like the British.
and their objectives were not the same as his by any means.
Stillwell was also his ground force commander in Chiang.
So that accentuated the problem, rubbed it in a bit.
In retrospect, we had some people in China
People in the press and people in the diplomatic service who are sympathetic to the communists and were taking advantage of that time to help them out.
No one could see this plainly and say this is the case, but it caused one awful lot of disruption over there, even in the middle of the fighting.
Could you give me an example of that?
Well, yes.
You remember the problems General Hurley had when he came over there as ambassador to China.
I was in trouble with Davies and with Stewart, whether.
And it was very, very disruptive.
So you had mixed up in any of those things with Colonel Hurley in Chungking and the embassy and Stilwell commanding ground forces in Vermont and China and American ground forces in India.
Chenault was in control of all the air forces that Chiang had and had to be helping what we did and what the British did.
Then we go over and integrate all those forces into a British command, even though it was under American actual command.
still answered to a British man.
And it made things hard to keep the wheels turning.
Sure, it was towns.
And that's where I spent my hours around the clock.
My office hours ran from seven in the morning until two in the morning usually.
I had the best bunch of people I've ever had anywhere.
Under your command?
In my staff.
I didn't have a command.
Yeah, in your staff.
In my staff.
What rank were you when you left?
When I went to India in 43, I was a brand new colonel.
In August of 44, I was promoted to Brigadier General, so I was a general officer the rest of the time.
Brigadier General the rest of the time I was there.

Okay, now getting back to, I want to talk about the generalship later, but getting back to Asia, it's your contention then that the communists in Asia during the war were disrupting the situation and making relations between the allies even worse.
Well, not so much the communists.
Well, yes, that's true, although that was not the major thing that I was referring to in that at all.
Mao Zedong and his communists and whatnot had pulled back and were consolidating and building their own strength.
And of course they were fighting the Japanese too.
Sure they were, yeah.
They had nothing to gain from the Japanese.
They allegedly were helping us and they did help a little bit.
They let us put in a weather service up through that area.
They were looking for Did you ever visit that Weather Service?
Well, yes, I operated it, butand I went up there, I think, twice.
Did you ever meet any of those people?
Oh, yeah.
Did you everwho did you meet?
Well, Charles Charles Lyme?
Yeah, and Mao.
You did?
Yeah, and Gee, I didn't know them.
I didn't have a great deal to do with them, but I did meet them.
Well, tell me about those meetings.
Well, one went up there to try to put in, to say a weather service is stretching the point a little bit.
What we tried to do was to indoctrinate about 30 Chinese people
in how to read some crude instruments that we give them to give wind direction and velocity and temperature and humidity.
And to get that to another one of their people who could get it to the radio station so it could be sent out and we could pick it up.
I'm trying to think of the name of the man who
built all these things.
Very famous guy, makes me mad.
I don't remember, and I'll have to get that name for you.
He made the anemometers out of spoons and thermometers out of
alcohol and straws and eggs with the centers taken out.
These kind of things that give them a way to do it.
Spillhouse.
Spillhouse?
Yeah.
Who later became dean of science at the University of Minnesota?
That's right.
Sure.
I know him personally, but we've interviewed him as a matter of fact.
I know him very well personally.
I've met a lot of them.
A lot of times, a lot of nights with him then and since then.
He's an interesting character.
He was a consultant to me out at the Jet Propulsion Lab as a matter of fact.
And so the one time that I went up there and I talked with Mao about what it was we were trying to do and how we wanted to talk to some of the people to get it lined up.
So Spillhouse and a couple of the others did most of the talking with those people.
They were up there for a couple of weeks, two or three times.
I was only up there for that one day, one visit.
Then after the war ended, it was after the Japanese

through Natal, but prior to September 2nd formal training, Mao and Chao and three of the others, and I've forgotten who they were, came down to Chongqing at the American ambassador's request, and I've forgotten now whether that was
General Hurley or the man who followed him, one or the other.
Anyway, they came down there and they landed at Chongqing in a DC-3, which was about the biggest airplane you could get into Chongqing.
And I had been to India and had come back to Chongqing, except I landed at a military base about 20 miles out and drove in.
And I drove in to the Chongqing airport.
in time to join the group that went to meet them, which was a delegation from the embassy.
I mean, the American ambassador wouldn't go out there to meet this particular group, so he sent somebody.
And I just joined them, went out and talked with them there for a while.
And then I went to, and I talked with Chang while they were there about some aspects of their visit.
And I never did, I didn't see any more of them.
I had no further contact with either one of them.
Now, they were up in, wasn't it, Yunnan Province?
Yes.
During the war, what were their living conditions like up there?
Well, they were damn primitive.
That's what I thought.
Very, very primitive, and almost on a starvation situation.
But so was everything else in China almost.
It wasn't comparatively so terribly bad.
How did they treat you when they went up to Yunnan?
Oh, very nice.
They had nothing to lose from the things they did with me.
I stationed a man up there and left him up there at the headquarters.
He stayed up there
I don't know, three or four months.
And collected this weapon, got it out, and he ran Was he American?
Yes, he was the U.S. Air Force officer.
And he ran some, handled some missions out of there, some fighter missions against the Japanese.
And they just didn't bother him either way.
I mean, the communists didn't.
I'm sure they watched down carefully what he did, but they didn't try to interfere in any way.
Were they cordial to you, or suspicious?
Do you remember what they said?
Well, they were real cordial and all, and they of course didn't act suspicious, but they were looking at the long range thing.
There wasn't anything in the short range that they were worried about.
We weren't going to attack them.
China didn't have the capacity to attack them.
Both of us were fighting the Japanese.
weren't anything to be worrying about.

They could just sit and try to consolidate themselves as well as they could and get past the present crisis and try to survive, which they did very well, you see, because when the war ended and as a result of lack of agreement at that particular conference, a decision was made to move
several of Chiang's divisions from the south, and even from Burma, up into the area of Pekin, Tencent, and all in order to hold it from the Communists.
And we did move by air at the end of that pipeline starting way back in India, which made it one hell of a job.
And we got them in place, and they consolidated their position, and we're in firm control of Pekin, Tencent, and the whole northern area.
But things turned sour back here in the U.S., and the China lobby, and all of the trouble in the State Department, and everything else.
So the ships that were supposed to supply those
nationalist Chinese that we moved in never did get there.
And the troops sat there, out of ammunition, out of food, and eventually were taken over by the Communists.
General Marshall went there with his mission, if you remember, to try to ameliorate that situation.
And he probably did for a couple of weeks or so, but
in the long run went on to the communists and the nationalist divisions were holding home and whatever material they had went to help the Maoist forces.
Were the British and the Americans back in India with your post, were any of the British and Americans worried during the war, 1944 and 1945, about
the possibility of communism in Southeast Asia or in China itself?
Both of us were, very much.
Do you remember any examples, any specifics?
Well, I remember, of course, a lot of specific conversations about it, but in terms of actions that would have anything to do with the course of the war, no.
Because, you see, Russia was not active over there in that theater at all.
and the Chinese communists then were the only communist forces that had to reckon with and they were isolated and didn't have a damn thing to fight with and weren't trying to get in a battle anyhow.
So militarily there was very little that happened over there that had any impact either way.
seeing the writing on the wall a long ways off, lots of us didn't like it.
And in retrospect, you can certainly see what was being planned if you read Teddy White's book, Thunder Out of China, and several others that have written since then.
And that was being planned right there at that time.
Teddy White and that woman that worked with him, Annalee Jacoby.
Hell, they were in our headquarters half of the damn time.
No kidding.
Trying to ride our airplanes everywhere one would go.
One or the other would be there trying to be on it to go.
Again, they weren't there acting as communists.
They just wanted to get the story?
They, well, it was a little more than that.

They wanted to get a story all right, but their mind was pretty well made up, and it's like a lot of the people that you've seen since that time, who, they don't want to say they're communists or anything, but they don't miss a single opportunity to degrade anything that's U.S., anything that's American, to make a damn how good it is, why it's bad, there's something wrong with it.
same thing in the communist side of the house, it's either never mentioned or it's praised in an entirely different light.

And that was kind of the way with Teddy and with Jacoby and Davies and Davies' wife and Stuart, although I really shouldn't be getting on record about those particular things, Stuart and Davies, because that's
that had its airing in proper form, decisions were made.
Now as far as joint planning, joint planning seems to me, from what you've said, to be pretty close between the British and the Americans at the Southeast Asia Air Command.
Did that come to an end immediately after Japan surrendered, or how long did it take for that planning to collapse?
I mean obviously there's no need for it, the war is over, but I mean as far as post-war planning or anything like that.
Was there a switch then?
Well, yes and no.
It was strictly joint military planning at our level, at a theater level.
There was really not much to do except
How did we disengage and get our people and our materials out and take care of accountability for them?

Decisions had to be made of whether you were going to let the British have all these on Lind's lease, whether you were going to destroy them, or whether you were going to try to ship them back to the United States or ship them somewhere else, Japan for example.
And so there was a great deal of joint planning went on in that line under, with directed objectives.
It wasn't a question of deciding what's best for, at my level of course, it had been at some other level.
That having been done, then there's really not much left for a theater level to do.

We had already moved long before this to China, and as of the time the Japanese surrendered, I was in Chongqing, and in October I had already moved to Shanghai, and Southeast Asia Command, that is Southeast Asia Air Command, no longer existed even then.
And so the joint planning at theater level disappeared just as fast as we could dispose of the problems we faced as a result of the end of the war.
We didn't do any forward planning as to what we would do in the theater because everything that was on an American mind was get out of here and get home.
Sure, demobilization.
Not only there, but here also.
It was the same thing on their mind.
I stayed longer in order to consolidate an awful lot of records that were over there and then to go to Japan and present the Air Force operations in India and China.
to the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey, that group that Sure, wrote all the reports.
Wrote all those reports.
Paul Nitsche was the deputy of that at that time.
I met Paul in Tokyo at that presentation.
I've known him ever since.
I don't envy him his job up to this morning by a damn sight.
No.
Trying to clean up after Haig and Gromyko left last night over in Geneva.
I was wondering about Ambassador Patrick Early.
There have been a lot of accounts of course written about

those years in the mid and late 40s in China in our role, and some historians and journalists have reported that Hurley was not the most capable man in dealing with that role, and I was wondering what your response to that is.
I guess I might be a little prejudiced.
I don't know.
You know, General Hurley was a good many things before he became Ambassador to China.
And he was, in addition to anything else he might have been, he was a good politician.
I'm not sure I know all the things that go into a good politician.
And my relationship with General Hurley was such that I didn't have an opportunity to make the kind of judgments that
that are being called for by these people.
I have a notion that a good many of them had even less of an opportunity, but they made the judgment anyway.
My contact with him, well I had met him two or three times here in the United States when he was Secretary of War or something else, but he wouldn't have remembered my name even.
when I went to India, he was already in China for the Sexton Conference.
He was going to go to the conference from Chongqing.
And General Stratton and I were going from New Delhi, India.
So, General Hurley

thumbed a ride over the hump, which was the only way he could get there to New Delhi, and then went with us from New Delhi to Cairo, and spent the time with us in Cairo until he went home with Chang and Madame Chang.
Oh, I don't know, after four or five days, whereas I stayed on two or three weeks and worked on other things.
But Donald Stratenbauer's airplane was a B-24,
combat B-24.
It had two niceties in it.

Under the top gun turret there was a bench that you could sit on, and in the back where the side gun turrets were, we had cleaned out some of the communications equipment and put two narrow bunks down there.
Otherwise it was a combat B-24 with a combat crew and armed and gunned and everything else.
On the way to Cairo, Della Hurley and I rode in the belly on these two little bunks that we had put on.
And it's quite a long way from New Delhi to Cairo.
It sure is.
So we had quite a bit of time to talk, and we did.
in spite of the roar and four engines, and tend to be quite loud talk.

I found him to be a really delightful person, a real fine sense of humor, and a wide, wide knowledge of, in some cases, detailed knowledge of a wide range of subjects, and an acquaintance with people that I just couldn't believe.
I mean, he just knew everybody.
And every one of them.
By the time we got to Cairo, I had a very great respect for him.
I didn't get to see very much of him after we got back.
Well, of course, he was in Chongqing, and I was in New Delhi, and that's further apart from San Francisco and New York.
Well, it's about as far apart.
In that time, it was no way to get there.
So I saw him four or five times up there and talked with him.
But I didn't get to know him as associated with the decisions that were being currently made.
Obviously, it was a hell of a lot of fire where he was pointing the smoke.
And when you have someone in your own organization who is undercutting you, particularly your number two man,
going to be problems.
I don't care what the job is or what the organization is."
And so he had a real ugly one there.
And I guess for my money he handled it just about as well as you could, considering the support that he didn't get from the States.
I think back here in Washington,
If you look back now at what happened shortly after that, you could say that one espousing the ideas that General Hurley had would be undercut on every side in Washington.
the same as I mentioned a minute ago, when Chiang Kai-shek's troops, having been moved into position, were allowed to sit there and starve to death and didn't get support.
We wouldn't have moved them in if we hadn't provided for the support in advance, but it didn't make it.
And I'm not sure where it went, but...
I think it was deep-sixed.
So you blame the Truman administration now?
Well, I hate to say administration.
I really blame the China lobby in the Congress.
